Ideological primacy. That’s the state of assimilating an idea into your “self” and then believing that idea is a part of your self. Once there, the mental defenses will lash out at any attack on that idea as if you were attacked personally. This can be seen in all sorts of places: Ever see two idiots fight over a sports team?Ever see two idiots fight over whose religion is the right one?Ever see two idiots fight over whose nation is better?Ever see two idiots fight over the inherent value of a political ideology over another?Ever see two idiots fight over a favorite/hated movie?We could go on and on. It is LITERALLY impossible to establish a purely objective value over matters of subjective taste. It almost always comes down to “because people say so”. There are objective measures, of course (“this team wins more games”, “that fast food chain sells more soylent-burgers”), but that is almost NEVER what people argue about. They assign a value to a thing and then demand that others see it. This is largely a sociological security behavior. When we value a thing, we inherently want others to share that value and get offended when people reject that thing. The more valuable (see: religion) the more vicious the reaction to rejection (duh!). We seek trust mechanisms — a pedigree that tells us “this person is safe”. The oldest two being common culture and common religion. (they usually overlap). The Parable of the Well fits best. I approach the only well for miles. I see a man in the distance I don’t recognize. My guard goes up. Could this man rob me? Could he murder me? Who will provide for my kin? As I get closer, I see a similar skin color and the marking on his robes are familiar, but clearly not from my village. Okay this feels a bit better, he’s not from beyond the highlands. But I’m not entirely sure. I hail him as I get within shouting distance. He responds happily. Okay, this feels a bit better, but he has a bit of an accent. It sounds like he’s from the tribe of the north. We know very little about that tribe. This could be dangerous. As I approach further, I give him the greeting of the Moon Goddess, and he smiles back with the same greeting. Now I feel much better. People of the Moon Goddess have almost no history of violence against their own kind. The code of the Moon Goddess is something I know well and her followers are sworn to protect each other and help in time of need. At the well, we connect quickly and it turns out he attended the Festival of Seven Sacrifices to the Moon Goddess three seasons ago, where I was introduced to my future wife. My youngest sister is of age and needs a husband and his youngest brother is of age and needs a wife. This is an opportunity to share between these two families and we agree to meet back at the same well two New Moons from now with our fathers and mothers in order to discuss the matter. That’s just one fictional, but realistic example, of how ethics and common trademarks of our “selves” act as pedigrees of our trust between our kind. History has fluctuated and the definition of our “kind” comes and goes with prosperity. In times of lean, it contracts, perhaps as close as immediate blood. In times of plenty, it expands to incorporate people we’ve never met. So why the “scientific racism” (note: I’m using that term, but there’s no such thing — there’s only racism based on stupidity). The Nazis attempted “scientific racism”. Primacy was: “Our kind [white, Aryans] are superior, comely, noble, smart, civilized. Those other kind are not. We will confirm that ideology that we already demand as fact [“primacy”] and the science must be made to support it [confirmation bias; cherry-picking]. As things happen, we will find things that correlate and then call it causation [post hoc ergo propter hoc].” See: Moral Tribes: Emotion, Reason & the Gap Between Us and Them - Joshua Greene
